title: 111_s3272
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2010" includes a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2010" imposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2010" imposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying. Section 216 of this title punishes those who violate this ban. A conforming amendment is made to Section 207(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 3 amends the time limit for Congressional staff under title 18, United States Code. SEC. 4 introduces a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database. SEC. 5 addresses the issue of the lobbyist revolving door to Congress. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving that position, unless waived by the Committee on Ethics or Standards of Official Conduct for a compelling national need. Lobbying contacts must be related to pending legislative business to be considered substantial. Contacts related to pending legislative business, solicitation of funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising exceeding personal contributions are considered substantial lobbying contacts. Simple social interactions with members or staff do not qualify as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6. Payment for charter flights by campaign funds and disclosure of certain air travel with a lobbyist by a senator. The amendment clarifies rules on the use of campaign funds for flights on commercial aircraft, specifying that political committees cannot make expenditures for travel by a candidate for federal office or on behalf of such a candidate. The amendment clarifies rules on the use of campaign funds for flights on commercial aircraft, specifying that political committees cannot make expenditures for travel by a candidate for federal office or on behalf of such a candidate. The amendment also includes a disclosure requirement for trips involving registered lobbyists or agents of foreign principals. SEC. 7 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to ban lobbyists from making cash campaign contributions. SEC. 8 amends the Lobbying Disclosure Act to require reporting by substantial lobbying entities. A substantial lobbying entity must annually report to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate any former congressional staff person who meets specific criteria, including salary thresholds and job titles. The filing required by this section must contain job descriptions and work experience of employees, individuals under contract, or consultants. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will include a database of 'Substantial Lobbying Entities'. The Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings of substantial lobbying entities to the District of Columbia United States Attorney for oversight. Substantial lobbying entity refers to an incorporated entity with more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 9. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Amends the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
